Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
September 9, 2025 and September 25, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing
rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days
from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective action
plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately please contact the area manager, Rorie Dodge-Pifer at (517) 899-6024.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4111 Job description
• (1) An institution shall provide a job description for each staff position that
identifies rules, required qualifications, and lines of authority.
Two of three new employee files had a job description that was signed after the
date of hire.
CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff
qualifications
• (1) Child caring institutions subject to 42 USC 671 shall not permit a child
caring institution staff member to begin working unless all of the following
has been completed using the forms, and in the manner, prescribed by the
department:
2

• (a) A criminal record check as referenced in R 400.4113(f), including
a fingerprint based check of national crime information databases,
unless an alternative criminal history check has been approved by
the federal government.
Two of three new employee case files reviewed had fingerprints completed after
the hire date of the employee.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee records for each employee and
shall include documentation of all of the following information prior to
employment or at the time specified in this rule:
• (c) Verification of high school diploma or GED when specified by rule.
Two of three new employee files did not have a verification of a high school
diploma.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee records for each employee and
shall include documentation of all of the following information prior to
employment or at the time specified in this rule:
• (j) A written evaluation of the employee's performance within 30 days
of the completion of the probationary period or within 180 days,
whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the employee's
performance annually thereafter.
Three of six employee files did not have adequate written documentation of
employee's performance. Two new employee files did not have a probationary
evaluation, and one ongoing employee file did not have an annual evaluation.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee records for each employee and
shall include documentation of all of the following information prior to
employment or at the time specified in this rule:
• (e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to employment
from persons unrelated to the employee and which are less than 12
months old.
One of three new employee files did not have three dated references prior to date
of hire.
CCI Rule 400.4121 Direct care worker; qualifications
• (1) A direct care worker shall have completed high school or obtained a
general equivalency diploma (GED).
3

Two of three new employee files failed to document verification of a high school
diploma.
CCI Rule 400.4152 Initial documentation
• (1) At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in the resident's case
record:
• (h) A brief description of the circumstances leading to the need for
care.
Three of three youth case files failed to document the circumstances that led to the
need for care in the initial documentation.
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan
• (1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and date an initial
treatment plan for each resident within 30 calendar days of admission.
One of three youth files reviewed did not have a completed initial treatment plan
within 30 calendar days of admission.
CCI Rule 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; updated treatment plan
• (1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and date an updated
treatment plan for each resident at least once every 90-calendar days
following the initial treatment plan.
Two of three youth files reviewed did not have a completed updated treatment
plan within 90 calendar days following the initial treatment plan.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
4

Maltreatment in Care
There was 1 substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Special Investigation 2025SIC0000760 with CAP approval date of 09/10/2025 was
a result of the agency staff grabbing and pushing youth and failing to engage in
appropriate behavior management techniques. The agency has submitted an
approved corrective action plan and has begun working toward achieving
compliance.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with that plan is as follows:
Special Investigation 2025SIC0000760 with CAP approval date of 09/10/2025 was
a result of the agency staff grabbing and pushing youth and failing to engage in
appropriate behavior management techniques and agency staff also engaged in
the use of derogatory language toward youth. The agency has submitted an
approved corrective action plan and has begun working toward achieving
compliance.
Financial Overview
Sumpter House is operated under Spectrum Human Services. Spectrum Human
Service Inc. is a 501(c)3. Their financial audit was reviewed and found fiscally
sound. No issues or concerns were noted.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator Assessment was received and reviewed on 09/08/2025.
Assessment indicates there were not any barriers or systemic factors impacting
rule compliance. Sumpter House staff continues to work toward enhancing
treatment for youth in the program and specifically motivating the youth to attend
and participate in clinical intervention. The assessment indicates the agency
continues to adjust to the transition from a mother/baby program to a program for
males ages 10-17. They are looking forward to the continued gradual increase in
the number of youth in the program.
5

Staff and Youth Interviews
A total of four staff were interviewed: two direct care workers, one case manager
and the Chief Administrator. The direct care staff spoke positively regarding their
employment with the agency and working with youth in the program, however a
request for increased presence of the supervisor during shift was expressed. The
staff shared some of the challenges including working with one of the youth who
destroys property, however improvement were noted after recent medication and
therapeutic intervention. Staff were knowledgeable about the policy and
procedures for Sumpter House, and all felt the training provided/required by the
agency has been helpful. No further concerns were reported.
Three youth were interviewed at Spectrum House as a part of the Interim
inspection. The youth provided positive feedback about the program and
interactions with staff. Youth did express challenges relative to peer relationships,
but reported things are improving. Youth spoke positively about staff and the
program in general. No areas of concern were reported by the youth.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An onsite inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on 9/09/2025 and
9/25/2025. There were no issues or safety concerns noted. The facility was found
to be well maintained and prepared to meet the needs of the youth placed at the
facility.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
